Legit fit red pills:

- Cardio doesnt kill gains, at least at any reasonable level. You can and should if you want run 20 miles per week or do other cardio forms, wont impact your ability to put on muscle. Just compensate with food

- If you're natty you only need 3-4 days in the gym. I used to be a natty daily gym guy , you can make quick progress but eventually you stall out. Recovery is actually a thing

- Good news: people will tell that you work out within 6 months pending where you start. Within 1-2 years you can reach somewhat close to your natty max and have all the benefits of respect from peers and women checking you out. Bad news: after that additional gains has depreciating returns, and outside of lift numbers you wont get additional recognition from peers

- Use barbells, get on a program, you wont get 'too big' ever unless juicing. Once you can do 1/2/3/4 and are 12% bf or less you've made it. From there can continue to get stronger but you're officially athlete build that stands out to average blokes

- social media is cancer. Lighting, dehydration, pump have MASSIVE impact on how jacked you looked. If you see a pic of someone shirtless that is likely with everything checked:angles, lighting, dehydration, pump, etc. They dont look like that in the morning

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69249589
I fried chicken, fried onion and put a few asian things for flavor and sauce like söy sauce, oyster sauce, rice vinegar, ginger, garlic, sugar, chili, hoisin sauce. Also sesame seeds.
If you want to make a sauce like that, the simplest way is to mix söy sauce, sugar and either lime juice or rice vinegar until you taste and think that there's a perfect balance between salt, sweet and sour. Then when you learnt that basic feeling you can add other suitable asian things, my first recommendations would be ginger and garlic. Sesame oil is great for east asian flavor too.
Usually I make something like this but mix everything together with noodles instead of having it with rice. Putting a fried egg on top is good.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I have no pictures, but I made a really tasty stew.

Ingredients:
>1 large Yellow Onion
>1 large Carrot
>1 large Turnip
>3 Cloves of Garlic (I use the whole head)
>3lbs of White or Red Meat (Pork Surloin, Turkey Legs/Thighs have been used so far, but I think that Beef would work well here too. Haven't tried fish with it yet, but I imagine Halibut would be good here.)
>3 cups of Chickpeas
>2 Cups of Tomato Sauce
>1 Cup of Chicken Stock
>Salt and other spices you like (I like Garlic and Paprika)

Procedure:
Pregame: If you're using white meat, brine it overnight. It'll make it more tender and juicy.

If you're using dried chickpeas, stew them up in boiling water for a few hours or until the pea mashes into a paste in your hands with minimal effort.

1. If using cuts of meat, bake in the oven for 1-2 hours at 300 degrees Fahrenheit. You want the meat to not be raw, but you don't want it cooked either. This is to make it easier to cut into smaller pieces or pull apart from any bones. Once ready, set aside for now.

2. Dice and fry onion, garlic, carrot, and turnip in a large pot or dutch oven until soft.

3. Add the meat into the pot or dutch oven, and mix around, keeping it all frying. Add salt and whatever other spices you like here.

4. Add the beans on top, and then the stock and tomato sauce. Mix it up, and then stir occasionally to make sure it doesn't burn.

5. Serve up after it's done boiling for a time. I like to have it with milk, and I like to put a dollop of plain Greek yogurt on top of it.

posts.com: How can I measure body fat percentage?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69263354
Grab a fatty piece on your body.
Pull it out until you can pinch the skin between your index and your thumb.
Is that piece thicker than 1 inch? if so you're above 20% body fat.
This is how calipers measure it and it's fairly accurate.
If you have more than one reading you can take (say love handles and stomach) the more accurate this becomes.
The closer or higher above one inch it is the fatter you are.
The closer it is to just literal skin between your fingers. almost to the point it seems paper thin the skinnier you are.
At some points you're so skinny you can't even pull the skin away from the body to measure it.
My triceps for instance are like this. I pull on the skin and can't even get it between my fingers without seriously pinching.
You want that on the major points.
The thigh, the ass, the stomach, the chest, and the love handles.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Honestly for me the ONLY benefit of a home gym is time savings. I'm someone who deeply values my time, and whenever I need to save as much as possible and every minute counts, I use my rudimentary home gym for a quick workout. Pull-up bar, Olympic rings, kettlebell, ez-bar with about 2 plates worth of weight, a mat for split squats/lunges. I can do a really quick and intense workout with what I got, superset and use everything to the utmost advantage.
However nothing can compare to the sheer usability of a complete gym, and unless you're some rich fag with a ton of cash to spend and space, a home gym will never have enough in it. Simply put, I like a wide variety of exercise and machine work, I only use the barbell for the bare necessities (bench, squat, Romanian deadlift) and since I go to the gym at the very least 4 times a week and gets me out of my small apartment, the ROI is good. That monthly fee is really not that much to pay for the activity itself.

And lastly I don't know about you, but I'm absolutely never as hype and motivated to workout at home, no matter the circumstances. Sure I drag myself around and force a workout out of my ass, or like I said if I'm pressed for time and need to squeeze a 30 minute super intense workout, yeah I'll use my home gym. But once I'm dressed up and inside the gym proper, nothing comes close because that's the sole, only reason I'm there. No distractions, no calls, people know I'm at the gym at that time so I don't get bothered. It's good.

posts.com:
>>69263306
The cost isn't much of a pro, if at all. Most people think they're going to get some super good craigslist deal and it'll be the perfect equipment that'll last 20 years. It won't. You'll spend more than you initially thought you would and you'll likely replace stuff way sooner than you thought, not because shit's broke, but because you just want something better/nicer. A lot of dudes make the mistake of skimping out on the bar. Yes, even the cheapest bar won't snap, but like half a year with a shit bar that permanently deforms and has shit knurling and non-existent bearings and you're going to start perusing Rogue's boneyard bars. Or some new cage attachment you "need", etc. And at the end of the day, you'll never have all the equipment that a decent commercial gym has.

Timewise it highly depends on you. A LOT of people I know do homegym now post-COVID and almost none of them get their workouts done any faster, and sometimes even slower. It's a lot easier to fuck around at a home gym, so much so that the few minute commute advantage is completely nullified. At a commercial gym, lots of people just tend to be more focused.

Not seeing others sucks. Not smelling others is fucking awesome.

I've focused a lot on negatives here but I have zero intention of ever going back to a commercial gym. I just don't want people throwing around what little cash /fit/izens have without knowing both sides.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
this depends how much of an enthusiast you are, you can certainly get most of the benefit of a gym with fairly cheap equipment
examples:

me and my bro got *850€* worth of pull-up and dip bars, squat rack, 140kg of non-olympic plates and barbell and curl bar, with the two of us paid for itself during covid, just as much as it would have had we been paying a gym subscription each

right now I train with *700€* 75lbs adjustable dumbbells, since this is enough right now for me to do all my exercises, it's technically pays for itself in two years but by then I will desire the 120lbs and 165lbs expansion kits, further driving up the cost up to *1400€*, which is three years worth of local gym subscriptions

my endgame homegym plan is a 30m2 homegym shed (6000€ probably) on rural propety, with a quality rack and cable crossover, a platform, some machines, gym flooring, etc will probably total around 21k€-25k€ once it's got all I want in there to make it my perfect training environment, it pays for itself in like 25 years for two users (that being said it really will be used that long unless I die of illness or freak accident)

so depending on your needs you may spend a negligible or a very high amount, but the savings in the wasted commute time, locker room time, not being able to do supersets and having to work in with others times, etc., not to mention that it can be used by multiple people and good equipment can be passed on, and if you are a remote worker or a father these way to save time can be very well worth it

previous: >>69203691

>Advice for new runners
- Try to keep your cadence high (at or around 180 steps per minute)
- Try to keep your heartrate in Zone1/2 (around an average of 55-65% of your max. heart rate)
- Build up speed and mileage SLOOOOWLY (start with 15 minutes, increase time/mileage by 10% per week)
- Yes, it will feel like you're going slow, you are; don't worry about setting good times for at least a couple months
- If you start to feel pain anywhere, stop and rest, then run a shorter distance next time or walk
- Don't worry about form, the human body knows how to run, just do what comes naturally
- Once you can comfortably run 6 mi. (10km), start thinking about a goal in terms of race distance and time, and look for a training routine for that race

>Does racing motivate you to run more even if you have no shot of winning the race?

Definitely. You always want to place well in your age group, even if you have no shot at the overall win. A top 3 in your age group, even a top 10 (if it's a large race) is nice.

It's also put-up-or-shut-up time.
When I just rooned, I would decide "I'm going to see what my best 10k time is." but then that would be like 2 weeks of me deciding "Nah, it's too hot today." or "Nah, I wasn't feeling it after the first 6km." Sure, I'd get a great time eventually, but I had so many shots at it, it was meaningless.

An early spring race encourages you to stay fit over winter because you want to do well in your season opener.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69259916
>serious muscle tear, lay off for a while, keep stretching,
if you think you have a serious muscle tear, see a physio, or doctor, or best case both.
Don't just do random mobility stretches.
You should work on general mobility if you're going from Couch to 5k.
dynamic movements to warm up before run.
stretching to cool down after run.

general stretching will improve mobility, which you want, but if done before run can cause issues.
Dynamic movements to get blood flowing and loosen the joints is the way to go before running.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I've been running regularly for a few weeks now, 3 days/week. If I want to improve my speed should I actively be pushing myself to go faster each week, or is that something that will just come to me naturally as I run more?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69260274
>m actually running faster on my last few miles once my legs stop buckling and feeling alive.
yeah, I know that one.
unironically... work on mobility, and flexibility.
If it hurts at the start, then you're too stiff, it feels good at the end because your body has finally relaxed.
This is a trap.
You think "I'm feeling great! I could do another 5!" you can't.
You were doing damage for the first 3 miles, and that will accumulate.

Do the mobility drills,
do your dynamic movments, and general stretching.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69260453
>>69260453
All the running programs list dynamic movements
I just work my way up from the ground, or down from the head.

Free easy clean movements, nothing jerky, with core held firm.

ankle rotations. clockwise, counter clockwise. 30 seconds each foot, each direction. (2 minutes)
Hip rotations, open up those hips. both sides, both directions. 30 seconds each leg, each direction (2 minutes)
Free swing legs from the hip. Frontal Plane, (forward backward) and saggital plane (side to side.) (you guessed it 30 seconds each leg, and plane, so 2 minutes)
I can't remember the name of the next thing, but it's basically Push Kick Drills, not fast just ... pick a spot on the wall, lift your foot up, touch that spot, touch it with toes... extend, push lightly off wall. Yeah, look they're just push kick drills, I can't think of another name.
https://youtu.be/ycdzg6aa6-A
1 minute.
then do some hip gyrations, and look, just do some basic fucking dynamic movements, gyrate hips, gently twist back, rotate arms, roll you neck.

then do 20 seconds of little hops in place.
THEN walk for 5 minutes as a brisk pace.

AND Then run 3 miles(5km) or even 6 miles (10 km) what ever your mid distance is, don't push it to the full 10 miles or whatever.

When stop, walk a couple of minutes, and then do all the standard static stretches.

>Why can't I just go out and run for 20 minutes? why is there 20 minutes of warm up cool down and...
BECAUSE the first half of your current runs are going to catch up with you.

The dynamic movements are to warm up, wake up and loosen up the body for short term mobility, so you don't hurt, and don't injure yourself.
The static stretches after wards are to increase range of motion in the long term.

You want strong flexible mobility, not loose and weak.
Hold each static stretch for 30 seconds for 3 reps, three times a week.
There's diminishing returns after 30 seconds.

>but point stands, if you have pain that doesn't heal, see a professional.
Fair I'll concede and simply keep it as "if it gets worse or doesn't heal within a week" have it checked out.

I've found through regular trial and error that daily full lengthening of a muscle is important.
Especially because I nightwalk a lot.
2 hours of walking at night + a full days work day after day led to regular issues involving overuse and minor muscle fiber tearing.
So every night before I go to bed I just do a basic assessment. In order
>squat first
>all flexor/extensors
>and finally quadratus lumborum
If it feels off I'll give it an extra bit of love.
Your legs take a beating that the rest of the body can't even compare to, so ensuring leg mobility daily is probably the most important thing a human can do.

Just my thoughts, but I really feel he will be fine. He probably just wasn't ready for how far he pushed his body and the fibers are really sore from how much he stretched them apart during the run.

>>69261299
Okay, oldboy's sprint warmup (mine, there are infinite permutations) for thought. This is for info purposes and has taken over a year to build up to from sessile lardiness...

Gentle walk into easy jog 400m (some sprinters won't jog more than 100m).
Toe walk then heel walk 20m ea.
Marching - high raised knee (hitting the "z" - raised hip, knees & ankles at approx 90 deg), straight backleg, driving arms in synch w/elbows bent.
Gentle skip 50m (like a child but with shoulders broad, sternum forwards and a bit of a swagger).
Switches (hitting the same shape/ posture as the march but with a pause each time knee is at top position LRLRLR etc)
Pedalling (ankle high - paying attention to dorsiflexion and ankle rigidity)
Hamstring sweeps
"Opening and closing the gate".
High knees (see Loren Seagrave stuff on youtube for example)
Leg swings (back to front and side-side)
A-skip 30m x 2.
Pedalling again, mid-shin height.
B-skip 30m x 2. Alternatively (similarly) "whip from the hip" drill (Seagrave again)
Double foot hopping then single foot hops on each side (work up from small number to start)
Gentle stride or two to shake legs out.
Lunges.
Big times (stick runs).
Maybe do some drop-jumps and reaction jumps
Faster strides then main session.

I try to get my ankles and achilles working early on as they have given me grief over the years. Our distance groups will do a reduced selection of the above, changing selection a bit each time and won't worry about dorsiflexion and ankle rigidity (switches and pedalling are not relevant for them).

Static stretching - all gentle - I tend to concentrate on the soleus, gastocnemius, hamstrings, hip flexors and shoulders.

As with all things, start with s small quantity of exercises and build up slowly as body allows.

If you're skinny, don't worry deeply about what foods you're consuming as long as it is not complete junk 100% of the time. You're in need of calorie count and large amounts of protein more than anything. If you're fat, cut out the junk and eat below your average calorie count. Skinny people need more big people need less if their goal is the opposite of where they're currently sitting.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69250035
Dieting has the most amount of broscience/mommybloggers, misinformation, misleading studies by supplement companies or product pushers, as well as just a general lack of nutritional education from public education. It literally takes years to unlearn a lot of the complete horseshit that people have been taught.

Weight loss is going to be highly personalized for each person because, well, we're all built a little different. But the general truths hold up; CICO is king and there are no exceptions. Anyone saying otherwise is bending the truth or trying to hide it behind something misleading.

For example, a lot of people proclaim keto as the best fat loss diet, without needing to cut out fat from the diet. but at the end of the day, the weight loss comes mostly from calorie restriction, not some magic ketosis.

If you count your calories and are consistent, you will be able to manage your weight without issue.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69250035
>Some say skipping breakfast is good, some say it's bad.
Skipping breakfast reduces calorie intake, but also makes you hungrier later. It’s just another way of doing intermittent fasting.
>Some say you should cut off all fat, sugar, carbs some say you shouldn't.
Carbs are fine, added sugar and added fat is not. If you eat whole foods that have some sugar or fat in them naturally, you probably won’t be fat.
>Some recommend fasting, some say you should eat more frequently.
Fasting is fine as long as you eat at least once a day.
>Some say cheating and eating bad food in moderation is okay, some say it isn't.
It depends on your personality. Some people are addicted and can’t have any, some people can eat one cookie a day and not have anything else bad.
>Some say you just need to eat less calories than you burn, some say that doesn't work.
You need to eat less, eat protein, and eat nutritious food.
>Some say you should lose weight slowly, some say you should do it faster.
1-2 lb a week is fine.
>Some say you should try this diet, some say this one.
Join the fruit, vegetable, and lean meat cult. We have delicious salads here.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69250035
Are you fat? Just think about what you eat. Do you eat a full meal as a snack at night (i.e. a sandwich or something like that)? When you have a burger, do you have one burger (+bun and whatever else) or two? When you make a sandwich, do you make one or two? If you eat breakfast, what do you typically eat? Do you regularly eat an entire large pizza by yourself? Do you eat dessert? Do you snack all the time? When you do snack, is it an actual portion at a certain time of day, or are you just grabbing a handful of something whenever you feel like it?

Realise that if you are fat, it's because you are eating excessively - you are eating an unreasonable amount. Just eat a reasonable amount, not for a week, not for a month, not until you reach your target weight. Adopt new, sensible eating habits which will be for life - this does not mean eating only salads or anything like that, it just means having reasonable portion sizes and cutting out stuff that you don't need and don't really enjoy (but just get a dopamine buzz from).

posts.com:
>>69252409
Whenever you’re doing higher rep ranges, it is normal to have some rep drop off. All that really means is that the final sets are to failure, whereas the first few have a few reps in reserve.

I would say stay at a weight until the rep drop off is minimal or gone, then increase weight.

So, for example, 12, 12, 11 is fine, and you can increase the weight. 12, 10, 7 is not, and you have to increase reps until you are strong enough to add weight.

posts.com: >During this time, I was still using a Westside Barbell-style system of programming. I was reluctant to change, as this system had given me gains in the past. I continued to use a lot of the principles of Westside, but had a lot of injuries. I also was very inconsistent because I was rarely performing the competition lifts. After a string of injuries and bomb outs, I took some time away from powerlifting. After moving to the Washington, DC area, I met Carlos Osegueda that runs Central Virginia Athletic and Barbell Club. He had been training with the Block Periodization system and making progress. At this time, I decided to research by reading Issurin’s Block Periodization: A Breakthrough in Sports Training and Principles and Basics of Advanced Athletic Training. These books gave me a better understanding and for the next year, I used trial and error along with the knowledge I gained to fine tune the programming to fit my needs. Using this system, I set a 190-pound total PR and gained my first Elite at 242.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Cold, poor and sleep deprived, but at least lifting is going well!

Wife veto'd me running on ice at night with no spikes, so ended up going into work and using the gym there. Banch, zerchers, rows, curls, and a slow 5K followed by 30min of cooking myself in the shower, curtesy of the office electricity bill.

Both bench and Zerchers are moving well. The zercher AMRAP is still limited by my ability to suck it up and ignore how awful high rep zerchers are, but still got enough to bump up my TM. In hindsight I could probably have banged out another 2, maybe 3 reps if I had just ignored the discomfort and braced hard.

To be clear there is no discomfort in my elbows or anything like that, it just sucks to perform the movement. I think because of how fucky it is to breathe and re-brache.

Foot/cuboid felt alright while running. Had to slow things down a bit and focus on how my feet were landing. just some minor discomfort while running, and not too big an increase in pain this morning. Might actually be back to running, just have to make sure I don't immediately overdo it.

After work yesterday we had the kids christmas show at school, then some cold hours of sledding. Ended up being pretty late before I was able to hit the gym, so wasn't in bed before 01.00. Up for work today at 06:00. Please send caffeine.

Anon out.

I did a bit of reading and I'm a bit unclear on something. Why would someone ever choose 3 day over 4 day? If I understand correctly each program aims to set a PR on squats and deads each week, with 3 day offering alternating PRs for bench and press (while 4 day has PRs for both each week). Also 4 day allows one to do more assistance/hypertrophy work. Would 3 day preferable only because it's less days in the gym? Or is there some benefit to the extra squat and deadlift volume that 3 day provides?

Also to be clear I'm referring to 3 day TM as outlined in PPST3 (with volume deads replacing power cleans) and Andy Baker's 4 day TM. Thanks for reading bros.

i am almost at 700 days of nofap. i still watch porn as in literally watch it with my eyes, but I don't cum and haven't for almost 700 days.

one interesting thing to note, my weight went up and down through this ~2 year range. nofap it doesn't give you infinite will or anything, but it does give a more masculine and dignified 'backdrop' to your thoughts and your personality. that being said, I felt more energetic and alive when I was more around ~200 days in the nofap when I was working out every day rather than now where I am working out a few times a week and eating junk here and there.

this is just a warning to everyone, in my complacency and laziness i have confirmed that you can override the benefits of nofap while being lazy on it. when I was around 200 days I was high-effort in basically all domains of life and I was in a great place spiritually. working hard all of the time, incredibly routined, felt alpha as fuck a lot of the time. things slowly fell apart, partially because I let work take over fitness (working a full-time job while finding a new job in the background and a new apartment) and then got used to not working out.
now that I have a new job and a new apartment, I am slowly getting back into the rhythm.

just a reminder to you brothers that there is nothing in life that can guarantee you won't fall off the train. money, happiness, a beautiful woman, good sex, nofap, good food, etc. etc. etc. You can still fall off the train and have it slowly fade away if you're not absolutely fucking obsessed with working out. but i digress.

we're all gonna make it. even if some of us are late to the party.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Nutrition pyramid edition

>Who is /fat/ for?
For fatties who are working towards a better physique through meaningful hard-work, strategy, and dedication. This is not QTDDTOT, stick to questions on fat loss. Post height and weight when asking for advice.
Join our Fatty Contest: https://www.fattycontest.com/

>What do I do first?
1. Read https://physiqonomics.com/fat-loss/
2. Calculate your Body Fat Percentage: https://fitness.bizcalcs.com/Calculator.asp?Calc=Body-Fat-Navy
3. Calculate your TDEE: https://www.sailrabbit.com/bmr/
Remember to use bodyfat% and use Katch-McArdle Formula with sedentary settings or your TDEE will be too high.
4. Plan your weight loss: https://www.losertown.org/eats/cal.php
5. Track your nutrition with MyFitnessPal (better for packaged food), Cronometer (better for generic food/macros) or LoseIt (great for both).

>Now what?
Count calories, all of them.
Eat about 500-1000 less calories than your TDEE.
Buy scales, be accurate.
Learn to cook. Try to stick to lean protein and green vegetables.
Eat a lot of protein. 0.72g per lb of goal lean body mass.
Doing cardio, even just walking, will improve your health. There is no such thing as a healthy fat heart, but you can offset the risks.
Lifting weights will keep and gain muscle mass and burn fat much quicker. No lifting results in the body burning away muscle AND fat.
Drink more water.
Read the /fit/ sticky: https://liamrosen.com/fitness.html

>DON'T
Eat refined sugars, they're terrible for you regardless of calories.
Eat processed foods.
Drink your calories (alcohol, soda, starbucks).
Freak out over a weight loss stall. Plateaus can last up to three weeks.
"Reward" yourself. Cheat days cheat only yourself.

>Other resources:
Loose skin, gyno & stretch marks: https://weight-loss-side-effects.netlify.app/
Reddit wiki: https://www.reddit.com/r/loseit/wiki/faq

>Don't think so
This gets posted in fast every once in awhile and always gets deboonked.
Glycogen + water is stored in the liver and muscles.
When fasting, glycogen will get massively depleted.

The redditard did his dexascan before refeeding.
>Total Mass (g): Total: 66448 or 66.4 Kg
>Fast ended 16/08 @ 68.2 Kg
He should have done the dexascan after 18/08 where his glycogen water weight stabilizes after refeeding.

Here's a little calculator you can use to estimate how much glycogen and water weight your body can hold.
(15 to 25 g of glycogen) X (4 to 5 g of water) X (Kg of LBM) / 1000

Now lets calculate.

>Lowest and highest estimate for Glycogen + water weight
(15 to 25) X (4 to 5) X 54 kg / 1000 = 3.2 to 6.75 Kg

>Change in Lean+ BMC
54 - 46.9 = 7.1 Kg

>Actual change in Lean+ BMC
7.1 - (6.75 to 3.2) = 0.35 to 3.9 Kg

>>69261111
>26 years old father of three
Based.

If you don't have much time and want to have a more complete physique you can do this:

>Switch pull-ups with chin-ups
You'll get the same back gains but you're training your biceps too, still not as good as adding an isolation exercise for biceps, but better than nothing.
>Add a single dead hang at the end of the workout to train forearms
Do it while L-sitting to train abs and optimize your time, it takes max 3 minutes if you are strong and you can wear a weighted backpack to reduce the hanging time. You can also do it everyday if you want because forearms regenerate quickly because they are small muscles.
>Do a set of lateral raises everyday
It takes 2 minutes and it will complete the V shape look, if you don't have any weights you can buy some cheap dumbell or there are ways to do them with your bodyweight, just search "bodyweight lateral raises" on YouTube.
>Switch push-ups for weighted dips.
Dips are harder, so you need to do less reps to reap the same benefits wasting less time in the process. Put a weight that allows you to do 8 reps for max time/gains ratio.

If you need weights, you can buy a sack of cement of 50 lbs for 3 dollars and put it in bottles and then in a backpack and do your exercises. Of course it would be better to buy a bar and plates, but as a mid twenties dad of 3 I assume you don't have much money to spend and it would be a bit of a waste if you then only do short workouts.

As someone who was extremely addicted to other people's validation, I'll tell you this. You will try to hit the wall, again and again. You will fail again and again. You will feel like shit because you will think to yourself that surely you deserve at least *something* at this point. That people "worse" than you have something you don't have.

What works is that in a way you have to give up and let go of expectations. You enter the room and you don't think to yourself "okay, it's time to be cool, time to make impressions", you just enter the room, that's it. There should be nothing beyond you just living and trying to be in harmony with yourself, having a good time. No expectations. Just live. Keep lifting, forget about proof and all that shit, it might never come in the way you want. You have to be okay with not having something you really want, no matter how much you think you deserve it. Take this advice to heart.

>>69258628
You’re 18; things are going to be fine. I literally didn’t start working out until I was 19 and that’s because I got jumped by my ex’s new BF at the time. Initially, I worked out in pure anger. That works for awhile, but as anyone will tell you, you can’t carry that stuff around forever. The. I’ve had stages in my life I was so depressed that I would stumble into the gym at 6am high because working out was nearly the only thing I was doing right for myself. The, once my life settled down, I actually fell into a good, constant routine and actually made some decent gains. Then i had a kid and lost most of them. Now I’m back at it with renewed purpose.

The point I’m trying to make here is life is full of twists and turns. Me personally, I was accomplishing so much outside of just working out that I didn’t seriously start lifting until I was 30, though I had already been working out on and off for ten years at that point. In that same time I had girlfriends, went from incredibly anxious and awkward to more mellow and self aware, gained confidence in myself, gained and lost friend, went to school, etc. None of these things in my life had to do with lifting in and of itself, but it was just a on and off constant I had in my life if I needed to do something right for my body and mind. Lifting isn’t going to accomplish much on its own, but it does teach you how to stick with and work at something that can be incredibly difficult to do. Just keep building yourself up as a person and you’ll be fine - you have time and don’t get impatient and think this will all happen overnight.

Honestly, if I had your build at 18, I would have been fucking slaying left and right. I was 5’8” and 115 lbs when I was your age. There’s some perspective for you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: As someone who has trained and competed in many different martial arts over the course of my life, I would say kickboxing/muay Thai. I think it's better than boxing because of leg kicks, anybody can throw a punch but when leg kicks are involved, its throw them off guard. One good leg kick would put someone on their ass pretty quick. I would also recommend training MMA style BJJ no gi grappling so you're not completely clueless on the ground but I would not recommend resorting to it unless it is a 1v1 fight. I don't recommend training sport BJJ because Pulling guard and trying to get a Dela heva is going to get your head stomped in.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69256244
Boxing. Condition your hands to hit without gloves on, and know what areas of the body to hit with a close fist without breaking your hands. Open palm strikes to the head or other bony areas are best. A solid palm strike to the temple or jaw can fuck someone up (assuming you’re not a DYEL) even with their guard up. Look up Bas Rutten’s fighting style for reference. Retards talking about kicking, BJJ, karate, or Krav Maga are clueless. Kicking in a real fight should be used sparingly as it makes you extremely vulnerable (if I catch your leg I can break it or throw your ass on the ground, it takes you off balance while you’re kicking, etc), Karate is mostly for show, BJJ is great when you’re on the ground or for submissions, but you don’t want to be on the ground at all in a real fight so it should only be a last resort, and Krav Maga is barely even useful for a real knife fight. You don’t want to get in a knife fight btw even if you’re seriously skilled you’ll likely get stabbed and cut a few times it’s a shit situation to be in. All of this isn’t even factoring in a scenario in which there are multiple people or you are taken by surprise, both of which are more likely to happen. At least know the basics of punching/submissions, and carry a gun or knife.

The real answer is any that has you sparring regularly. Really, it doesn't matter. When you get in an actual fight, you're going to rely on instinct and if you can default to any moves that actually work and are more efficient than just throwing haymakers, you'll wipe the floor with anyone unless they're way above your weight class.

Muay Thai, BJJ, Boxing, whatever. It doesn't matter. Do what you enjoy. You could make arguments for one being better than the other but really you're way more likely to come across somebody who has minimal training than end up in some Youtube video titled "BJJ VS MUAY THAI STREET FIGHT".

>>69256244
>For 1 on 1 encounters:
A combination of BJJ, Wrestling and Judo. In a real world fight, everything is going to happen in less than 10 seconds. In all likelihood, the only thing your opponent knows how to do is throw a few wild haymakers at your head and hope he knocks you out before he runs out of gas. If you can get him on the ground and control his arms, he's probably going to be helpless. This video is a good example. Black kid is tough shit when he's throwing punches, but helpless as a toddler as soon as the white guy grabs him and he can't throw no more: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hGIVCD8lBH0

>For 1 vs. a group encounters:
#1 is knowing how to run the fuck away as fast as you can.
#2 if you can't run, is probably just boxing. If you go to the ground against multiple opponents, then you are basically dead. You have to stay on your feet, stick and move as much as possible, be explosive and overwhelming, and try to end it as quick as possible. The guy in this video is probably the perfect example: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9rA3M9i74lY

Self defence, ranked by effectiveness, from my experience as an mma fighter:

posts.com:
Squats are weird. concentric comes after the eccentric so you can trick yourself into thinking you did it right. Anyone can lift more weight at parallel than a2g. and you can lift even more by only going to half depth.
That's why people fuck themselves up on squats so much. They try to a2g their parallel max, or they try to parallel their half-squat, and so on. Find your a2g max and then train that, at that depth. Your tendon health will improve if you do this right, and degrade if you equivocate on depth

I swallowed my pride, dropped down to 1pl8, and really mastered the form and attendant flexibility/mobility/stabilization needs. I'm back at 3pl8 now, ATG, and my quads are way bigger and more defined than they've ever been, especially the teardrop and area around the knee. They were never this big and defined back when I was maxing out on parallel squats, and as a bonus my hips and knees feel better than they ever have before. The caveat is that you have to start light and be really serious about the accessory stretching/mobilization/stabilization/form work if you don't want to hurt yourself. If you take it seriously though, it is perfectly safe

Parallel. I tested this. Did 3xf atg highbar then 4xf zerchers atg. Another week did 3xf parallel lowbar then 4xf zerchers atg. The way I do zerchers is all quads, ass and core, so it's obivous lowbar parallel hits those muscles more than highbar atg. Not to mention parallel lowbar hits stabilizers harder as you are using significantly more weight. Highbar is dogshit, lowbar + front/zercher/hack whatever to isolate quads, and deadlift + stiff legged deadlift/whatever on another day to isolate hams is best.

Your upper back is folding. You need to create a more stable shelf, you need to think about pushing the bar back and up with your upper back as you start to go up, and you need to add front squats/zerchers to strenghten the upper back. Zerchers are best because it's a simpler squat variation compare to front, but you need to pay attention to a) not letting your hips rise faster than the bar where you sorta bend over as you start to rise up b) keep your arms by your sides, not in front, so your upper back is not rounded

posts.name: Anonymous

>>69259806
I think you're trying to stay too upright and looking too high for your proportions. Counterintuitive as it may seem, trying to keep your eyes and head up forces you to hyperextend your back as you go down, and instead of dropping your hips any lower to get below parallel, they shoot back as you bring the barbell down into a squat morning. Upright torso position is for people with diddy little legs, you need to accept a degree of forward lean throughout the squat and your eye position needs to reflect that. Try looking at the floor in front of you, maybe even as close as a few feet away. Keep your eyes fixed there from the moment you unrack, keep your spine neutral, push your upper back into the bar but don't crank your head back. If you just sit in a bodyweight squat with a neutral spine and see where your eyes naturally want to look, that will probably give you a starting point to try out.

>>69262744
Clen isn't a stimulant in the same way that caffeine or meth are stimulants. It's a stimulant in the way that adrenaline (epinephrine) is a stimulant. Meaning it stimulates the sympathetic nervous system more than than the central nervous system (Beta-2 agonist specifically). The clen is essentially putting you into a flight/survival response that is overcoming the other things you may be feeling.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69264409
>Arched back allows more abs to activate
No, it's the opposite. The arching makes your abs stretch more, which is a good argument, but the only good argument.
When your legs are locked like this you can and will use your hip flexors which means much less ab activation. At least until you progress the weight a good amount because limited activation with heavy weight is still a lot of activation on account of the heavy weight.
But at that point you may as well do deadlifts and squats for your abs instead of a hip flexor excercise.
Note how in the OP he has to use his hamstrings to hang on. This disengages the hip flexors and makes it pure abdominal hell.
>easier to get started
That's actually a good point too. You should start with janda situps though and I"ll let you know when I figure out how to progress from there to the hanging situps.

posts.com:
>>69257577
So, your muscles dont really care about numbers. All they need is time under tension or in other words: 10-20 "hard" sets that are close enough to failure. Now I started lifting focusing on the classic compounds and developing my connection with the muscles but these days I just do 1-2 compounds or compound variants for a muscle or muscle group and then some isolations. Some examples: for shoulders I do 4 hard sets of seated DB OHP (rep range anywhere from 6 to 15), some drop set shenanigan lateral raises because they give me a sick pump and 3 to 4 sets of rear delt flys. One big compound, two isolations, 11 or so hard sets total. For legs I do squats, then leg press and then whatever "small" exercise I feel like. If I dont feel like squatting I say fuck it and just go really hard on leg press and vice versa.
Chest is a good example because I do some benching, sometimes flat bb bench, sometimes incline db bench, whatever I feel like. It only matters that its hard enough and gives you a sick pump. Round it off with two more exercises that are more Isolation types.
Idk how to explain but yeah. Hard big movement, burning small movements.

>>69263258
Because most impingement problems are caused by lack of scapular stability.
Dead hangs and pullups are the perfect way to both stretch the arm and train the scapula.

Impingement at the end of the day though requires three things.
1. enough time for swelling to go down.
2 mobility, eventually you will have to release the impingement and it will probably be painful.
3. fixing what is causing the impingement entirely.

until you do 3, lifting, serious lifting, is out of the question. you'll just make it worse.
like i said minimum 6 months.
Even with the dead hangs i'd use an assisted pullup machine or bands if you have the option.
Half body weight is enough to still enough to stretch the arm.

This is a calisthenics routine I did for a few months back when I was in the best shape of my life (start of 2019). Just loop the 3 days over and over. Or I guess you could make the 7th day of each week a rest day, to help recovery.

"Ab Day"
>12 mile run
>4000 sit ups
>8000 reverse crunches
>25x2 minute elbow plank
>10x2 minute each side plank
>850 hanging leg raises
>4x failure push up planks

"Chest & Back Day"
>16 mile run
>1500 standard push ups
>1000 close grip push ups
>1000 wide grip push ups
>600 pull ups
>600 chin ups
>1400 bench dips
>1x failure handstand push ups

"Leg Day"
>12 mile run
>150 bodyweight squats
>650 jumping lunges on each leg
>500 box jumps
>400 tuck jumps
>300 step ups each leg

The way the reps got broken up (ie into sets, to failure over and over until you finish, supersets, whatever) didn't matter. Those numbers just needed to be reached.
Except the running. That had to get done in one go

Unreasonable time investment for anyone who isn't a NEET tho.

The Leg day is less intense than the others so that I could actually run.

posts.com:
For a squat session:
Do your warmup however you do and work you way up to a 5x5 routine for the day. I currently go with 315 on this so I'll pretend you do to. Go through with the 5x5 sets and add weight if you think you can manage while still hitting 5 reps. The last and 5th set has to be till failure so minimum 6 reps.
Once that is done drop the weight to 275 and go for a set of 10. The drop to 225 and shoot for 15. The drop to just a plate and pump out 3 sets of 25.
After that just go through with the workout. This will get your legs pumped and burning.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I used to do this when I was training for Muay Thai, it was basically a cardio circuit that I could do every 2 days between trainings that helped with endurance etc.

Exercises: 5
Rounds: 5
Rest between exercises: 20 seconds
Time spent working: 40-50 seconds
Rest between rounds: 1 minute
Alternate between 2 different exercise for each exercise in different rounds, example below.

Exercise 1: Squat Jumps or Mountain Climbers

Exercise 2: Push ups or Plank To Push-up Position

Exercise 3: Kettlebell Shoulder Press or 1 Arm Kettlebell Swing

Exercise 4: Standing High Knees or Burpees

Exercise 5: Ab Walkouts or Plank Position

So you basically want to do 2 of each exercise by the time you’re done.
The exercises themselves aren’t actually that hard, but it’s the compounding in short bursts with little rest that builds up the acid & contracts the muscles tighter and at the end I’d always be completely fucked.
